A student interested in receiving need-based financial aid is required to submit a Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) for each school year. Once all the eligibility criteria are met and all necessary documents are obtained, either through review of the ISIR or by efforts of the Financial Aid Counselor, the financial need of the student is determined by the difference between the cost of attendance at Xavier and the EFC toward those costs. After the financial need for the student is calculated, the financial aid package for each student is determined by the Banner system based on the student's financial need, academic merit, talent, enrollment status, level in school, and dependency status. Award letters (via e-mail or regular mail) are then prepared and sent to each student, notifying them of what types of awards they are deemed eligible to receive. The student then has the option to decline any aid that is offered to them. Xavier uses passive acceptance of aid offered.

FINANCIAL AID INFORMATION IS PUBLISHED IN THE COLLEGE FOR CREATIVE STUDIES ADMISSIONS MATERIAL, WHICH IS GIVEN TO EACH STUDENT CANDIDATE, AS WELL AS ON THE CCS WEBSITE, WWW.COLLEGEFORCREATIVESTUDIES.EDU. ELIGIBILITY FOR NEED-BASED FINANCIAL AID IS DETERMINED BY AN ANALYSIS OF FAMILY RESOURCES FOR THE MOST RECENT CALENDAR YEAR TO ASSESS A FAMILY'S ABILITY TO CONTRIBUTE TO COLLEGE COSTS. ADJUSTMENTS TO AN APPLICATION CAN BE MADE BECAUSE OF A MAJOR CHANGE IN CIRCUMSTANCE, SUCH AS DEATH, DIVORCE, OR LOSS OF EMPLOYMENT/BENEFITS. TO RECEIVE FEDERAL OR STATE FINANCIAL AID FROM CCS, STUDENTS MUST DEMONSTRATE FINANCIAL NEED, BE ACCEPTED FOR ENROLLMENT IN A DEGREE-SEEKING PROGRAM, BE ENROLLED AT THE COLLEGE, MAINTAIN A SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS, AND BE A U.S. CITIZEN OR PERMANENT RESIDENT. IN ADDITION, A STUDENT MUST BE REGISTERED WITH SELECTIVE SERVICE (OR BE EXEMPT) AND CANNOT OWE A REFUND ON PREVIOUS TITLE IV FUNDS RECEIVED OR BE IN DEFAULT ON ANY STUDENT LOAN. ALL STUDENTS MUST COMPLETE THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA) TO BE CONSIDERED FOR NEED-BASED AID. THIS FORM IS AVAILABLE ON-LINE AT FAFSA.ED.GOV OR HIGH SCHOOL GUIDANCE OFFICES, OR ANY COLLEGE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE. THE RECOMMENDED FILING DEADLINE FOR HIGH SCHOOL SENIORS RESIDING IN THE STATE OF MICHIGAN WHO ARE CONSIDERING STATE AID IS MARCH 1ST. TRANSFER AND CONTINUING STUDENTS SHOULD SUBMIT THEIR APPLICATION BY MARCH 1ST AS WELL. THE FINANCIAL AID CYCLE FAVORS THOSE STUDENTS WHO FILE IN A TIMELY FASHION AND COMPLETE THE REQUIRED DOCUMENTATION EARLY. CCS' TITLE IV CODE IS 006771. GRANT/SCHOLARSHIP AMOUNTS ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY TO STUDENT'S TUITION ACCOUNTS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANTS AND OTHER ASSISTANCE
ExplntnTxt: SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2 THE COLLEGE'S FINANCIAL AID OFFICE MONITORS ALL RECIPIENTS OF SCHOLARSHIP AWARDS TO DETERMINE BOTH INITIAL AND CONTINUING ELIGIBILITY BASED UPON THE CRITERIA FOR THE TYPE OF AWARD. VARIOUS CRITERIA MAY INCLUDE, BUT IS NOT LIMITED TO, ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE, FINANCIAL NEED, OR OTHER CRITERIA ESTABLISHED BY DONORS OF SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: form 990, schedule i, part i question 1
ExplntnTxt: description of organization's procedures for monitoring the use of grants all scholarships are awarded based upon specific criteria. the financial aid ofFice, based upon the criteria, recommends scholarship awards to the scholarship committee. the scholarship committee reviews the recommendations and approves the recommendations. the financial aid office then awards the scholarships.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: form 990, schedule i, part iii column a
ExplntnTxt: types of assistance provided to individuals in the united states 292 scholarships were awarded to pay tuition and fees for students attending morehouse school of medicine in the m.d. and mph degree programs. total scholarships awarded were $2,971,232.

HERITAGE UNIVERSITY PARTICIPATES IN FEDERAL GRANTS AND LOAN PROGRAMS. ALL OF THE STUDENT AWARDING PROCESS IS DOCUMENTED IN THE SOFTWARE USED TO DETERMINE ELIGIBILITY AND TRACK STUDENT AWARDS. FOR THOSE AWARDS WITH SUBJECTIVE SELECTION CRITERIA, THE DOCUMENTATION IS MAINTAINED BY THE PERSON RESPONSIBLE FOR SUCH AWARDS OR GRANTS. HERITAGE UNIVERSITY UNDERGOES A YEARLY AUDIT OF THE GRANTS AND OTHER FEDERAL FUNDS IN ACCORDANCE WITH A-133; A-87; AND OTHERS.

ALL SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS WHO HAVE COMPLETED THE COLLEGE'S ADMISSIONS REQUIREMENTS AND HAVE REGISTERED FOR CLASSES. SCHOLARSHIPS REQUIRE A STUDENT TO MAINTAIN A FULL-TIME STATUS THROUGHOUT THE SEMESTER AND ARE AWARDED FOR ONE YEAR, DIVIDED EVENLY BETWEEN THE FALL AND SPRING SEMESTERS. MOST SCHOLARSHIPS ARE RENEWED ANNUALLY AS LONG AS THE STUDENT MEETS THE RENEWAL CRITERIA AND COMPLETES THE FAFSA. MUSIC AND ATHLETIC SCHOLARSHIPS REQUIRE RE-EVALUATION EACH YEAR AND ARE NOT AUTOMATICALLY RENEWED. SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED WITH THE UNDERSTANDING THAT A STUDENT WILL COMPLETE THE SEMESTER FOR WHICH THE AWARD IS RECEIVED. A STUDENT MUST BE IN GOOD STANDING AND MAKING SATISFACTORY PROGRESS IN ORDER TO RECEIVE A SCHOLARSHIP.

INSTITUTIONAL MERIT SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED ON THE BASIS OF DEMONSTRATED ACADEMIC EXCELLENCE AND PROMISE FOR FUTURE SUCCESS AT THE COLLEGE. WHILE A NUMBER OF FACTORS ARE CONSIDERED, THE COLLEGE RELIES HEAVILY ON THE EVALUATION OF HIGH SCHOOL COURSEWORK, HIGH SCHOOL GRADE POINT AVERAGES AND CLASS RANK, STANDARDIZED TEST SCORES, WRITTEN WORK AND LETTERS OF RECOMMENDATION. EXTRACURRICULAR INVOLVEMENT THAT DEMONSTRATES A PROMISE FOR SUCCESS AT THE COLLEGIATE LEVEL IS ALSO CONSIDERED. SCHOLARSHIP AWARDS ARE APPLIED TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT FOR PAYMENT TOWARD TUITION, ROOM, BOARD AND FEES.

IN PROVIDING FINANCIAL AID TO STUDENTS, THE COLLEGE ADHERES TO FEDERAL AND STATE GUIDELINES AS WELL AS INTERNAL CRITERIA SUCH AS ACADEMIC PROGRESS, FINANCIAL NEED, AND OTHER CRITERIA ESTABLISHED FOR PARTICULAR SCHOLARSHIPS. THE FEDERAL FAFSA FORM IS USED. STUDENT ACCOUNTS ARE DIRECTLY CREDITED FOR SCHOLARSHIPS AWARDED AND THEREFORE, NO CASH IS EXCHANGED.

SALEM GRANTS FUNDS IN THE WAY OF SCHOLARSHIPS TO QUALIFIED STUDENTS IN ITS ACADEMY AND COLLEGE. SALEM MAINTAINS RECORDS ON ALL STUDENTS RECEIVING FINANCIAL AID IN THE FORM OF SALEM GRANTS OR FROM OTHER SOURCES. SALEM COLLEGE COMPLIES WITH ALL APPLICABLE FEDERAL RULES AS IT RELATES TO COLLEGE FINANCIAL AID.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE I, PART III, COLUMN B:
ExplntnTxt: THE VAST MAJORITY OF SALEM'S COLLEGE STUDENTS RECEIVE SOME FORM OF SCHOLARSHIP FROM THE COLLEGE. SALEM PROVIDES THIS ASSISTANCE THROUGH ENDOWED SCHOLARSHIPS AND INSTITUTIONAL REMISSION (DISCOUNT). SALEM COMPLIES WITH ALL FEDERAL AND STATE REGULATION REGARDING THE REWARDING OF STUDENT FINANCIAL AID AND FILES THE REQUISITE INFORMATION WITH FEDERAL AND STATE AGENCIES AS IT PERTAINS TO ITS STUDENTS.

FORM 990, SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2 ADMISSION TO POMONA COLLEGE IS ON A NEED BLIND BASIS. THIS POLICY IS MAINTAINED TO ACCOMPLISH DIVERSIFICATION OF THE STUDENT BODY REGARDLESS OF THE FINANCIAL STATUS OF THE APPLICANTS. A PERMANENT FILE OF ALL STUDENTS WHO ARE RECIPIENTS OF SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS IS MAINTAINED IN THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE OF POMONA COLLEGE. AN ACCOUNTING SYSTEM TRACKS ALL AWARDS TO INDIVIDUAL STUDENTS FOR TUITION AND OTHER COSTS OF ATTENDING THE COLLEGE.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
ExplntnTxt: Administration, monitoring and oversight of grants is conducted to oversee the progress and completion of the grants, ensuring compliance with all relevant terms and conditions.

THE COLLEGE OFFERS SEVERAL SCHOLARSHIP OPPORTUNITIES FOR STUDENTS. THE PRIMARY SCHOLARSHIPS AND THE GUIDELINES FOR QUALIFYING ARE: FOUNDERS SCHOLARSHIPS - THESE SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS UPON ACCEPTANCE TO A BACHELOR OF SCIENCE DEGREE PROGRAM AT VAUGHN. TO BE CONSIDERED, APPLICANTS MUST ATTAIN A CUMULATIVE HIGH SCHOOL AVERAGE OF AT LEAST A "B AND A COMBINED SAT1 SCORE OF AT LEAST 1000. STUDENTS WHO MEET THESE MINIMUM CRITERIAS WILL BE CONSIDERED FOR AWARDS, BASED ON THEIR GRADES AND EXAM SCORES, BY VAUGHN COLLEGE'S SCHOLARSHIP COMMITTEE. THE AWARDS MAY BE RENEWABLE FOR UP TO FOUR YEARS OF CONSECUTIVE STUDY, PROVIDING THE RECIPIENT MAINTAINS A 3.0 CUMULATIVE GRADE POINT AVERAGE (GPA). BOARD OF TRUSTEES, #14 AND #36 GRANTS - THESE GRANTS ALLOCATE FUNDS TO BE USED IN AWARDING GRANT-IN-AID ASSISTANCE TO NEW AND CONTINUING STUDENTS. GRANTS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS WHO ARE MATRICULATING ON A FULL OR PART-TIME BASIS IN BACHELOR AND ASSOCIATE DEGREE PROGRAMS. RECIPIENTS ARE SELECTED ON THE BASIS OF THEIR ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE AND FINANCIAL AID STATUS. AWARDS ARE DESIGNATED FOR A SPECIFIC ACADEMIC YEAR AND ARE RENEWABLE EACH SEMESTER BASED ON SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE AND THE AVAILABILITY OF FUNDS. TRANSFER STUDENT SCHOLARSHIP - STUDENTS WHO TRANSFER TO THE COLLEGE HAVING COMPLETED 24 OR MORE CREDITS AT AN ACCREDITED COLLEGE OR UNIVERSITY, AND WHO HAVE ACHIEVED A CUMULATIVE GRADE POINT AVERAGE OF AT LEAST 3.0 (INCLUDING ALL COURSES AT EVERY INSTITUTION ATTENDED) MAY BE AWARDED SCHOLARSHIPS TO TRANSFER. THE AWARDS MAY BE RENEWABLE FOR UP TO THREE YEARS OF CONSECUTIVE STUDY, PROVIDING THE RECIPIENT MAINTAINS A 3.0 CUMULATIVE GPA. ACADEMIC EXCELLENCE SCHOLARSHIPS - ACADEMIC EXCELLENCE SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED EACH YEAR TO CONTINUING STUDENTS ON THE BASIS OF OUTSTANDING ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT AND SELECTION FOR ACADEMIC HONORS. THE CRITERIA APPLIED IN DECIDING ELIGIBILITY FOR THESE AWARDS INCLUDE CUMULATIVE GPA AND SATISFACTORY COMPLETION OF AT LEAST TWO SEMESTERS (29 CREDITS/UNITS OR MORE) AS A MATRICULATED STUDENT.

A NUMBER OF COLLEGE SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AVAILABLE TO DEGREE STUDENTS. COMPLETION OF A SCHOLARSHIP APPLICATION FORM IS REQUIRED. FORMS ARE AVAILABLE THROUGH THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE. AN APPLICATION MUST BE SUBMITTED 30 DAYS PRIOR TO THE QUARTER FOR WHICH THE SCHOLARSHIP IS BEING REQUESTED.

ALL STUDENTS APPLYING FOR FEDERAL FUNDS ARE REQUIRED TO SUBMIT THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID ("FAFSA"). THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE REVIEWS THE RESULTS OF THE FAFSA, WHICH DICTATES WHAT AND HOW MUCH FEDERAL FUNDING THE INDIVIDUAL STUDENT IS ELIGIBLE FOR. IF THE STUDENT IS DETERMINED TO BE IN COMPLIANCE WITH ALL FEDERAL REGULATIONS, AS DETERMINED BY THE DEPT. OF ED., THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AWARDS THE STUDENT THE APPROPRIATE FUNDING. STUDENT FILES REGARDING ELIGIBILITY ARE MAINTAINED BY THE STUDENT FINANCIAL AID OFFICE.

THE THREE AREAS OF FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE TO STUDENTS ARE LOANS, GRANTS, AND EMPLOYMENT (WORK-STUDY). THESE ARE GENERALLY AWARDED ON THE BASIS OF FINANCIAL NEED, DETERMINED BY AN ANALYSIS OF FAMILY INCOME AND ASSETS. SCHOLARSHIPS ARE ANOTHER SOURCE OF FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE, AWARDED ON THE BASIS OF ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, ATHLETICS OR PERFORMING ARTS, COMMUNITY SERVICE OR LEADERSHIP. CRITERIA FOR MERIT BASED AWARDS MAY ALSO INCLUDE A FINANCIAL NEEDS REQUIREMENT. THE UNIVERSITY MONITORS THE AMOUNT ISSUED BY CALCULATING A COST OF ATTENDANCE, ASSESSING AN ESTIMATED FAMILY CONTRIBUTION (EFC), AND DERIVING A LEVEL OF FINANCIAL NEED. ONCE THE AMOUNT OF AID HAS BEEN DETERMINED FOR THE INDIVIDUAL, IT IS DISPERSED TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT AND IS CONTROLLED BY THE BURSAR'S OFFICE. SEVERAL REPORTS/SURVEYS ARE USED ANNUALLY TO MONITOR THE DISTRIBUTION OF GRANT ASSISTANCE; FOR EXAMPLE, FISAP REPORT TO USDE, A-133 AUDIT, FEDERAL IPEDS REPORT, STATE ANNUAL AUDIT, AND VARIOUS SURVEYS THAT TYPICALLY USE INFORMATION FROM THE COMMON DATA SET (CDS).

GRANTS ARE MADE IN THE FORM OF SCHOLARSHIPS AND STIPENDS TO ELIGIBLE STUDENTS. TOCC MAINTAINS RECORDS OF STUDENTS' QUALIFYING CRITERIA AND SEEKS TO ENSURE THAT EVERYONE HAS ACCESS TO QUALITY EDUCATION REGARDLESS OF NEED.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: MONITORING THE USE OF GRANTS IN THE U.S.
ExplntnTxt: PART I, LINE 2 ALL GRANTS OR OTHER ASSISTANCE TO DOMESTIC ORGANIZATIONS OR DOMESTIC GOVERNMENTS ARE AUTHORIZED AND INITIATED BY THE PRESIDENTS OFFICE WITH STRICT CONTROLS OVER THE SELECTION AND DISTRIBUTION OF THE FUNDS. ALL SUCH GRANTS WERE MADE TO 501(C)(3) ORGANIZATIONS OR DOMESTIC GOVERNMENTAL ENTITIES. FINANCIAL AID IS AWARDED TO STUDENTS IN THE FORM OF MERIT-BASED SCHOLARSHIPS, NEED-BASED GRANTS, WORK-STUDY AND STUDENT LOANS. ELIGIBILITY FOR FINANCIAL AID VARIES BASED ON THE CRITERIA OF EACH AWARD. MERIT SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED BASED ON ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT SUCH AS HIGH SCHOOL GRADE POINT AVERAGE, SAT OR ACT SCORE AND CLASS RANK, AND/OR EXTRA-CURRICULAR ACTIVITIES AND RECOMMENDATIONS. NEED-BASED GRANTS ARE OFFERED TO STUDENTS WHO COMPLETE A FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA) AND WHO, BASED ON THIS INFORMATION, MEET THE ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS FOR THE NEED-BASED AID. ALL STUDENTS WHO ARE SELECTED FOR VERIFICATION BY THE CENTRAL PROCESSING SYSTEM (CPS) MUST ALSO SUBMIT VERIFICATION OF THE INFORMATION PROVIDED ON THE FAFSA. NEED-BASED GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS INCLUDE THE FEDERAL PELL GRANT AND FEDERAL SUPPLEMENTAL EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITY GRANT (SEOG), STATE GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS, AND EMMANUEL COLLEGE GRANT AID. IN ADDITION TO NEED-BASED GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS, STUDENTS WHO APPLY FOR FINANCIAL AID AND DEMONSTRATE FINANCIAL NEED MAY ALSO RECEIVE FEDERAL WORK STUDY AND NEED-BASED FEDERAL AND STATE STUDENT LOANS. THE LOAN PROGRAMS OFFERED BY EMMANUEL COLLEGE ARE THE FEDERAL STAFFORD LOAN, THE FEDERAL PERKINS LOAN AND THE MASSACHUSETTS NO-INTEREST LOAN. PRIOR TO DISBURSING ANY FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE, STUDENT ELIGIBILITY FOR EACH GRANT, SCHOLARSHIP, WORK-PROGRAM OR STUDENT LOAN IS CERTIFIED. TO RECEIVE NEED-BASED FINANCIAL AID STUDENTS MUST APPLY FOR FINANCIAL AID EACH ACADEMIC YEAR.

Students' eligibility to receive financial assistance from Concordia University Chicago is determined by policy approved by the Board of Regents. On a basis of careful analysis of the financial statements, the Director of Financial Aid determines the amount of aid available from various sources. Next, the amount that the student and his or her family can reasonably be expected to provide is calculated. The difference is called "demonstrated need." Financial assistance is awarded based on the student's demonstrated need for that year. Concordia-Chicago provides scholarships. All recipients are unrelated except for tuition benefits provided under Concordia-Chicago's tuition grant program to eligible employees, their spouses, and dependents. This tuition grant program is in accordance with IRC section 117(d). Concordia University Chicago also provides student assistance through work-study.

THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID DETERMINES A STUDENT'S ELIGIBILITY BASED ON THE FAMILY'S FINANCIAL STRENGTH, WHICH INCLUDES CONSIDERATION OF FAMILY INCOME AND ASSETS, NUMBER OF CHILDREN IN COLLEGE AND IF APPROPRIATE, SPECIAL CIRCUMSTANCES. FINANCIAL AID WILL BE REVOKED WITHOUT ADEQUATE PROGRESS.

The University has numerous procedures to ensure students qualify for scholarships and other assistance both at the time of the award and subsequent thereto. These procedures ensure compliance with applicable Federal and state regulations, stipulations and scholarship criteria and University policies for awards made by the University.

SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2: THE COLLEGE AWARDS SCHOLARSHIPS AND OTHER ASSISTANCE TO QUALIFIED INDIVIDUALS ON THE BASIS OF FINANCIAL NEED AND ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT. THE AWARDING OF FUNDS IS MONITORED BY THE COLLEGE'S FINANCIAL AID OFFICE, WHERE A COMPLETE LISTING OF RECIPIENTS IS ALSO MAINTAINED.

OUR FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AWARDS SCHOLARSHIPS TO STUDENTS BASED ON SUBMITTED FAFSA DATA AND ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE IS RESPONSIBLE FOR ENSURING COMPLIANCE WITH ALL RELEVANT STATE AND FEDERAL REQUIREMENTS RELATIVE TO GRANT-BASED AID.

CCA MERIT SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS THAT COMPLETE ADMISSION APPLICATION REQUIREMENTS BY THE PUBLISHED DEADLINE AND ARE BASED ON ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT AND PORTFOLIO REVIEW. NEED-BASED SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS WITH DEMONSTRATED FINANCIAL NEED AND ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT. RECIPIENTS OF NEED-BASED SCHOLARSHIPS AND SEOG FUNDS MUST COMPLETE A FAFSA APPLICATION, BE US CITIZENS OR ELIGIBLE NON-CITIZENS, AND BE ENROLLED FULL-TIME.

YESHIVA UNIVERSITY CONDUCTS SITE VISITS AND FOLLOW-UP DISCUSSIONS WITH THE MANAGEMENT OF GRANTEES TO ASSURE THAT GRANT FUNDS ARE USED FOR THE INTENDED TAX-EXEMPT PURPOSES. THE ACTIVITIES OF FELLOWSHIP RECIPIENTS ARE MONITORED TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE WITH THE INTENTIONS AND GUIDELINES OF THE FELLOWSHIP GRANT.

THE $88,209,736 IN GRANTS AND ASSISTANCE REPRESENT STUDENT FINANCIAL AID, SCHOLARSHIPS AND FELLOWSHIPS, INCLUDING EMERGENCY STUDENT ASSISTANCE GRANTS. FINANCIAL AID IS AWARDED BASED UPON FINANCIAL NEED AND ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT. NEED BASED AID IS AWARDED BASED ON ELIGIBILITY DETERMINED BY THE US DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION'S FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL AID (FAFSA). ACADEMIC BASED AID IS AWARDED BY THE DISTINGUISHED SCHOLARS COMMITTEE. BOTH FACULTY AND ENROLLMENT SERVICES ADMINISTRATORS COMPRISE THE COMMITTEE.
THE COLLEGE MONITORS ELIGIBILITY FOR THESE AWARDS BY ASSESSING STUDENT RECORDS, FINANCIAL NEED AND ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE. SCHOLARSHIP COMMITTEE REVIEWS APPLICATIONS FOR AWARDS.

DECISIONS REGARDING FINANCIAL AID ARE MADE BY THE STUDENT FINANCIAL AID OFFICE. THE GOAL IS TO PROVIDE ADEQUATE FINANCIAL AID TO APPLICANTS WHO, WITHOUT SUCH AID, WOULD BE UNABLE TO ATTEND THE UNIVERSITY.

With respect to scholarships, interested students complete an application which is reviewed by the scholarship committee to determine if they meet established criteria. Funds are then awarded to the applicants who best meet the criteria. The amount of money available will determine how many scholarships are awarded. A portion of these scholarships are awarded to students based on financial need and nationality. Students who are awarded scholarships are monitored with respect to their scholastic achievement as students must maintain certain grades to retain their scholarships.

Part I Line 2 THE UNIVERSITY GRANTS LISTED ON SCHEDULE I REPRESENT SCHOLARSHIPS OFFERED TO STUDENTS WHO MATRICULATE AT THE UNIVERSITY. AS SUCH, NO MONITORING OF THE GRANT FUNDS ARE REQUIRED BECAUSE THE STUDENT MAY ONLY USE THE SCHOLARSHIP FUNDS TO DEFRAY THE COST OF TUITION.

The University's Enrollment Services Division, Office of Student Financial Services, and Office of Research Services and Sponsored Projects responsible for the administration of all grants and student aid according to current law, regulations, and policies prescribed by grantors. The University is subject to annual audits conducted in accordance with OMB Circular A-133.
The Organization awards grants to students to be used for educational purposes by debiting the students account directly. This system ensures that the funds are used appropriately.

Each charitable contribution or scholarship is monitored by Franciscan Missionaries of Our Lady University. The University has set different levels of monitoring depending upon the amount of the contribution or scholarship. Donor restrictions, if applicable, are considered in the level of monitoring performed.

FOR INDIVIDUAL RECIPIENTS OF GRANTS, ACADEMIC EXCELLENCE AND DEMONSTRATED FINANCIAL NEED ARE USED TO DETERMINE EACH STUDENT'S FINANCIAL AID. THE FINANCIAL AID CONSISTS OF ANY COMBINATION OF GRANTS AND LOANS AND ARE REVIEWED EACH YEAR BASED ON A STUDENT'S ACADEMIC RECORD AND/OR DEMONSTRATED NEED. THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID, WHICH HELPS TO ESTABLISH A STUDENT'S FINANCIAL NEED, SERVES AS THE APPLICATION FOR TUITION SCHOLARSHIPS.

EACH GRANT IS ASSIGNED A SEPARATE DEPARTMENT ACCOUNT NUMBER. REPORTS ARE THEN PRINTED WHICH SHOW ALL FUNDS RECEIVED AND DISBURSED. THESE GRANT REPORTS ARE PRINTED ON A MONTHLY BASIS BY THE PERSON RESPONSIBLE FOR THE GRANT. THE ACCOUNTING DEPARTMENT ALSO PRINTS GRANT REPORTS ON A MONTHLY BASIS AS A CHECK THAT DISBURSEMENTS ARE NOT GREATER THAN FUNDS RECEIVED AND THAT FUNDS ARE BEING DISBURSED FOR GRANTS APPROVED.

CARTHAGE COLLEGE OFFERS SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS TO QUALIFIED STUDENTS TO HELP REDUCE THEIR OUT-OF-POCKET TUITION COSTS. STUDENTS RECEIVING FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE OF THIS FORM MUST MEET SPECIFIC CRITERIA SUCH AS ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, FINANCIAL NEED AND OTHER SIMILAR STANDARDS WHETHER PUT IN PLACE BY THE COLLEGE OR BY DONORS OF RESTRICTED FUNDS.

THE UNIVERSITY MAINTAINS RECORDS TO ENSURE FINANCIAL AID IS AWARDED TO ELIGIBLE STUDENTS BASED ON CRITERIA IN INDIVIDUAL SCHOLARSHIPS, AS WELL AS FEDERAL REGULATIONS, OR DONOR RESTRICTIONS. FEDERAL GRANTS ARE AWARDED BASED ON FAFSA INFORMATION.

The primary responsibility for financing a university education rests with the student. Financial aid from the University and other sources is viewed only as supplementary to the efforts of the student and the student's family. Students requesting financial aid are expected to contribute toward their educational expenses through summer or university employment and/or loans in any reasonable combination. Financial aid is an important factor for many students, and 100 percent of eligible Manchester University students receive some combination of grants, scholarships, loans, and work. Student Financial Services will determine a student's eligibility for financial aid by using the results of the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA); the estimated family contribution (EFC) and review of edit (c-codes), as well as the student's academic records and funds available. Manchester University utilizes an awarding matrix based on a combination of academic and financial need criteria referenced above. Student Financial Services administers financial aid from federal, state, and institutional resources utilizing the federal guidelines established by the U.S. Department of Education. The following steps must be taken by a student to receive a financial aid package from Manchester University: 1. Apply for admission and be admitted to Manchester University. Eligibility for academic scholarships from the University is determined through the admission process. 2. Submit a FAFSA. Eligibility for federal, state and institutional need based grants and loans is determined through this process. The student must designate the results be sent to Manchester University, and Indiana students must have a receipt date between Oct.1 and April 15 to be considered for state grant eligibility. 3. Submit any additional documentation requested by Student Financial Services. Enrollment Requirements. Students receiving financial aid must maintain full-time enrollment, (a minimum of 12 semester hours) in each of the fall and spring semesters. There are circumstances in which part-time students demonstrating need may be awarded financial aid depending on the guidelines and availability of federal, state and institutional funding. Part-time students must enroll in a minimum of six hours to maintain eligibility for institutional funds and loans. Degree Requirements. Students must be working toward their first baccalaureate degree to be eligible for federal, state or institutional grants and scholarships. Students who have completed a baccalaureate degree are eligible for loans only.

MONITORING USE OF GRANT FUNDS - CLEVELAND INSTITUTE OF MUSIC CREDITS THE GRANTS AND OTHER ASSISTANCE DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENTS' ACCOUNTS AND THEREFORE ENSURES THAT THE FUNDS ARE SPENT FOR EDUCATIONAL PURPOSES. WORK-STUDY AND AUDITION ASSISTANCE ARE PAID DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENTS WHEN EARNED OR INCURRED.

THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID DETERMINES ELIGIBILITY OF EACH STUDENT WHO APPLIES FOR FINANCIAL AID, USING FORMULAS AND CRITERIA PROMULGATED BY VARIOUS FEDERAL, STATE, AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTAL BODIES, AS WELL AS MARYWOOD'S INTERNALLY ESTABLISHED RULES AND PROCEDURES.

IN AS MUCH AS ALL GRANTS ARE FOR NON-CASH ASSISTANCE FOR STUDENT RECIPIENTS' TUITION, ROOM, BOARD OR BOOKS, WHEN SUCH REMISSION OCCURS, IT IS A DIRECT REDUCTION OF THE STUDENTS FEES TO THE UNIVERSITY. SINCE NO GRANT FUNDS ARE IN DIRECT CONTROL OF THE RECIPIENT, THE RECIPIENT IS NOT IN A POSITION TO DIVERT THE GRANT FROM ITS INTENDED USE.FOR ATHLETIC SCHOLARSHIPS, THE ATHLETIC DIRECTOR AND DIRECTOR OF STUDENT FINANCIAL SERVICES, TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE WITH NAIA RULES, MUST MONITOR SCHOLARSHIP EXPENDITURES FOR EACH STUDENT AND PROGRAM.

FEDERAl GRANT FUNDS ARE AWARDED IN COMPLIANCE WITH FEDERAL REGULATIONS APPLICABLE TO THE SPECIFIC PROGRAM. INSTITUTIONAL PROCEDURES ALLOW FOR SEPARATION OF AWARDING AND DISBURSING OF FUNDS. STUDENTS WHO RECEIVE SCHOLARSHIPS AND FEDERAL WORK STUDY FUNDS ARE MONITORED EACH SEMESTER FOR ACADEMIC PROGRESS. ANNUAL AUDITS ARE CONDUCTED BY AN EXTERNAL AUDIT FIRM TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE WITH ALL PROGRAM GUIDELINES.

PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS ALL SWARTHMORE COLLEGE SCHOLARSHIPS ARE DISBURSED/POSTED ELECTRONICALLY (AND INTERNALLY) DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENTS ACCOUNT. FURTHERMORE, STUDENTS RECEIVING SAID FUNDS ARE UNABLE TO WITHDRAWAL IT FROM THEIR STUDENT ACCOUNT.

ALL GRANTS ARE AWARDED ONLY AFTER CONFIRMING A STUDENT'S ELIGIBILITY -CONSISTENT TO ALL GRANT CRITERIA. EACH SCHOLARSHIP AND GRANT IS RECONCILED AT THE END OF EACH SEMESTER AND AWARD YEAR TO VERIFY STUDENTS MAINTAIN ELIGIBILITY. REPORTS MONITORING GPA, CITIZENSHIP, FEDERAL AND INSTITUTIONAL ELIGIBILITY ARE USED TO AWARD AND ENSURE RECONCILIATION FOR EACH FUND.

SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS ARE DETERMINED BY PROGRAM COMMITTEES AND ARE RECORDED ON STUDENT LEDGERS. EACH PROGRAM SELECTS ITS INTERNAL SCHOLARSHIP AWARDEES, SUBJECT TO REVIEW BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE. THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AWARDS SDS SCHOLARSHIPS. THE UNIVERSITY ACCOUNTING OFFICE MAINTAINS RECORDS OF AMOUNTS AWARDED AND DISBURSED.
AWARDS TO STUDENTS ARE MONITORED THROUGH OUR FINANCIAL AID OFFICE.
THE FOUNDATION MONITORS ELIGIBILITY FOR THESE AWARDS BY ASSESSING STUDENT RECORDS, FINANCIAL NEED AND ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE. THE SCHOLARSHIP COMMITTEE REVIEWS APPLICATIONS FOR AWARDS.

GRANTS AND OTHER ASSISTANCE TO INDIVIDUALS ARE PROVIDED IN THE FORM OF STIPENDS TO RESIDENTS, POST-DOCTORAL AND GRADUATE STUDENTS. THE STIPENDS ARE SUBJECT TO ALL OF THE PAYROLL SYSTEM CONTROLS, TIME SHEETS, EFFORT REPORTING AND OTHER PAYROLL CONTROLS. THE REMAINING GRANTS USE TUITION SCHOLARSHIPS WHICH ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY TO TUITION AND FEES WITHIN THE ACCOUNTING SYSTEM TO WHICH THE STUDENT HAS NO ACCESS.

THE ORGANIZATION REQUIRES STUDENTS WHO RECEIVE ASSISTANCE TO COMPLETE APPLICATIONS FOR ASSISTANCE AND DEMONSTRATE THEIR NEED. ONCE ASSISTANCE IS RECEIVED BY A STUDENT THE ORGANIZATION MONITORS THE STUDENT TO ENSURE THAT THE COURSES FOR WHICH ASSISTANCE WAS RECEIVED ARE SUCCESSFULLY COMPLETED.

JOHN F KENNEDY UNIVERSITY IDENTIFIES ELIGIBLE GRANTEES AS PER REGULATIONS FOR EDUCATIONAL PURPOSES AND COMMUNITY SERVICES. GRANT FUNDS AND GRANTEES ARE MONITORED AS APPROPRIATE PER REGULATIONS THROUGH PERIODIC AND ANNUAL REPORTS.

MONITORING USE OF GRANT FUNDS - THE COLLEGE ENSURES THAT ITS GRANTS OF STUDENT FINANCIAL AID ARE USED FOR THE INTENDED EDUCATIONAL PURPOSE BY APPLYING THE AWARDS DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENTS' TUITION BALANCES INSTEAD OF ISSUING CHECKS. THE COLLEGE ALSO MAKES ENTREPRENEURIAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL GRANTS THROUGH ITS LAUNCH U PROGRAM AND GREEN EDGE FUND. POTENTIAL GRANTEES SUBMIT APPLICATIONS FOR THE GRANTS, AND AFTER A RIGOROUS REVIEW PROCESS, GRANTS ARE AWARDED. GRANTEES ARE REQUIRED TO SUBMIT REPORTS WHICH INDICATE HOW THE GRANT FUNDS WERE SPENT.

THE UNIVERSITY ABIDES BY THE REGULATORY PROVISIONS SET ASIDE IN ALL GRANT AWARDS TO ENSURE PROPER FINANCIAL AND PROGRAMMATIC REPORTING. THE UNIVERSITY'S OFFICE OF SPONSORED PROGRAMS (OSP) PROVIDES OVERSIGHT AND MONITORING OF ALL GRANTS. OSP RECEIVED MONTHLY, QUARTERLY, AND ANNUAL REPORTS FROM ALL GRANTS FUNDED PROJECT DIRECTORS (PD) AND PROJECT INVESTIGATORS (PI) ASSOCIATED WITH THE IMPLEMENATION OF THE GRANT AWARDS. OSP MEETS WITH THE PDS AND PIS WEEKLY TO ENSURE THAT THE GRANTS ARE ON TARGET FOR COMPLETION. OSP WORKS CONJUNCTIVELY WITH THE DEPARTMENT OF ADMINISTRATION AND FINANCE TO MONITOR AND RECONCILE ALL FINANCIAL OBLIGATIONS WITHIN GRANTS AND CONTRACTS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: PART I, LINE 1:CRITERIA FOR RECEIVING A SCHOLARSHIP THROUGH THE UNIVERSITY
ExplntnTxt: THE MAIN DETERMINANT OF FINANCIAL AID IS NEED, AND ONE OF THE MAJOR ELEMENTS IN THE NEED EQUATION IS THE COST OF ATTENDING SCHOOL. STUDENTS HAVE DIFFERENT BUDGETS, DEPENDING ON WHETHER THE STUDENT LIVES ON OR OFF CAMPUS. STUDENT EXPENSE BUDGETS INCLUDE THE COST OF TUITION AND FEES, BOOKS AND SUPPLIES, A MONTHLY ALLOWANCE FOR ROOM AND BOARD, TRANSPORTATION TO AND FROM SCHOOL, AND PERSONAL EXPENSES SUCH AS CLOTHES AND ENTERTAINMENT. ALL STUDENTS ARE REQUIRED TO COMPLETE THE FAFSA, REGARDLESS OF INCOME, BEFORE NEED CAN BE DETERMINED. ONCE THE FAFSA IS COMPLETED AND THE RESULTS ARE RECEIVED AT THE INSTITUTION FROM THE FEDERAL CENTRAL PROCESSOR, THE INSTITUTION WILL USE THE EFC (EXPECTED FAMILY CONTRIBUTION) TO AWARD FINANCIAL AID.

The College determines the eligibility for each student's needs, the awards are credited to the student's account and the Office of Financial Aid monitors the student's continued eligibility to receive the assistance.

All scholarships are awarded based upon specific criteria maintained by the financial aid office. Requirements for receiving scholarships depend upon other factors, such as grade point average, family income or economic need. The Colleges financial aid staff monitors the eligibility guidelines to ensure compliance. The College undergoes the required Uniform Guidance audit annually.

THE FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT ISSUES AND MONITORS STUDENT FINANCIAL AID AWARDS. THE FINANCE DIVISION MONITORS THE SCHOLARSHIPS AND DISCOUNTS REFLECTED ON STUDENT BILLING. STUDENT AID IS AWARDED ACCORDING TO THE COLLEGE'S PROCEDURES. STUDENT AID IS AWARDED BASED ON MEETING ESTABLISHED CRITERIA WHICH INCLUDE ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT AND FINANCIAL NEED.

PIEDMONT COLLEGE PARTICIPATES IN THE STUDENT FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS THROUGH THE U.S. DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION. FUNDS ARE AWARDED AND DISBURSED TO STUDENTS BASED ON THE DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION GUIDELINES SET FORTH BY THE TITLE IV PROGRAMS.
USE OF GRANTS IS MONITORED THROUGH OBSERVATION OF THE ONSITE WORK OF THE RESEARCHERS.

THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE IS CHARGED WITH DETERMINING ELIGIBILITY, ALLLOCATIONS OF GRANT FUNDS, AND MONITORING OF STUDENT ACCOUNTS. FINANCIAL NEED IS DETERMINED AFTER AN ANALYSIS OF THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA) IS COMPLETED. THE UNIVERSITY ALSO OFFERS ACADEMIC SCHOLARSHIPS, WITHOUT REGARD TO NEED, TO ENTERING NEW AND TRANSFER STUDENTS WITH OUTSTANDING ACADEMIC RECORDS. ALL FINANCIAL AID IS CHARGED DIRECTLY AGAINST THE STUDENT ACCOUNTS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: FORM 990, SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2
ExplntnTxt: MONITORING THE USE OF GRANTS Emory University's student aid awards consist of need-based and merit-Based awards. Merit-based funding is awarded based upon donor preferences and restrictions or institutional academic criteria. Need-based aid is awarded based upon institutional methodology, a standard need analysis formula generally practiced by other private, non-profit peer institutions. Student financial aid is awarded to students for educational purposes. Award amounts are controlled by educational costs established by the institution and student progress is evaluated at key points in the student lifecycle if the award has contingencies that require such. Disbursement controls are in place that require direct costs be paid prior to providing refunds for non-direct educational expenses. Emory University is responsible for ensuring that it communicates the relevant and necessary information contained in subcontracted award documents to the subrecipients. The Office of Sponsored Programs maintains a copy of the Subcontract Agreement, which stipulates the terms of the award and is signed by representatives of both Emory University and the subrecipient organization. This agreement indicates that the subrecipient understands and is aware of the award requirements. In addition, if there are any further changes to the Agreement, an amendment to the agreement is generated and signed by the representative of Emory University and the subrecipient.

The financial aid office determines students eligibility for federal, state, and institutional scholarships according to the University's established criteria which follows federal and state guidelines for awarding any grant funds. There is an annual audit to ensure compliance with these regulations.

Disbursements in furtherance of the institution's exempt programs are made in accordance with procedures or subject to conditions established by the Institution's governing board designed to ensure that individuals and organizations receiving disbursements from the institution in furtherance of its exempt purpose are adequately investigated to insure that they are qualifying recipients. Students receiving scholarships and fellowships are judged worthy by the institution on the basis of criteria such as academic achievement (fellowships) and financial need (scholarships and fellowships).

PART I, LINE 2 ONE OF THE UNIVERSITY'S HIGHEST PRIORITIES IS TO REMAIN AFFORDABLE AND ACCESSIBLE TO THE MOST TALENTED STUDENTS, REGARDLESS OF THEIR FINANCIAL CIRCUMSTANCES. THE UNIVERSITY'S ADMISSION PROCESS FOR UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS FROM THE UNITED STATES IS NEED-BLIND, WHICH MEANS THAT STUDENTS ARE ADMITTED IRRESPECTIVE OF THEIR ABILITY TO PAY; THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDES THE FINANCIAL AID NECESSARY TO MAKE STANFORD AFFORDABLE TO EVERY ADMITTED STUDENT. FOR INTERNATIONAL STUDENTS, THE UNIVERSITY IS NEED-AWARE: STANFORD ANALYZES THE NEED FOR AID AND AIMS TO MEET THE DETERMINED NEED. SINCE 2000, THE UNIVERSITY HAS CONTINUED TO ENHANCE ITS FINANCIAL AID PROGRAMS FOR BOTH ITS UNDERGRADUATE AND GRADUATE STUDENTS. CURRENTLY, FAMILIES OF UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS FROM THE U.S. WITH INCOMES BELOW $125,000 AND ASSETS TYPICAL OF THAT INCOME LEVEL RECEIVE AT LEAST ENOUGH SCHOLARSHIP TO COVER THE COST OF TUITION. THOSE WITH INCOMES BELOW $65,000 AND TYPICAL ASSETS RECEIVE ENOUGH SCHOLARSHIP ASSISTANCE TO COVER TUITION, ROOM AND BOARD, AND OTHER EXPENSES. IN FY18, APPROXIMATELY 47% OF UNDERGRADUATES WERE AWARDED NEED-BASED FINANCIAL AID FROM STANFORD. STANFORD PROVIDES VALUABLE FINANCIAL SUPPORT TO ELIGIBLE GRADUATE STUDENTS WHICH ENABLES THEM TO PURSUE THEIR ADVANCED STUDIES. FUNDING MAY TAKE DIFFERENT FORMS, SUCH AS FELLOWSHIPS AND ASSISTANTSHIPS, AND THESE IN TURN FURTHER THEIR GRADUATE PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT AND PROGRESS TO DEGREE COMPLETION. IN THE CASE OF GRADUATE RESEARCH AND TEACHING ASSISTANTSHIPS AS WELL AS FELLOWSHIPS, THE FUNDING COVERS PART OF STANFORD'S TUITION (WHICH IS FREE OF INCOME TAX), IN ADDITION TO PROVIDING A STIPEND OR SALARY THAT HELPS STUDENTS WITH THEIR LIVING EXPENSES. BOTH COMPONENTS ARE ESSENTIAL FOR DOCTORAL STUDENTS IN PARTICULAR, AS IT TAKES SEVERAL YEARS TO GAIN THEIR MASTERY OF SPECIALIZED SKILLS AND CONTENT KNOWLEDGE IN THEIR CHOSEN FIELDS. GRADUATE STUDENT FINANCIAL AID AND OTHER SUPPORT IS AWARDED BASED ON ACADEMIC MERIT AND THE AVAILABILITY OF AID. IN THE FACE OF DIMINISHING FEDERAL SUPPORT, STANFORD HAS ASSUMED MORE OF THE FINANCIAL WEIGHT OF SUPPORTING ITS GRADUATE STUDENTS. IN FY18, APPROXIMATELY 79% OF GRADUATE STUDENTS RECEIVED FINANCIAL SUPPORT. THE KNIGHT-HENNESSY SCHOLARS PROGRAM IS AN ADDITIONAL SOURCE OF GRADUATE STUDENT SUPPORT. THE PROGRAM PROVIDES FULL FUNDING FOR THREE YEARS TO ENABLE GRADUATE STUDENTS TO PURSUE ADVANCED DEGREES AND DEVELOP THE CAPACITY TO LEAD AND BRING ABOUT POSITIVE CHANGES IN THE WORLD. THE TOTAL FINANCIAL AID INCLUDES $303,445,245 IN MERIT AND NEED-BASED SCHOLARSHIPS AND FELLOWSHIPS. AN ADDITIONAL $168,530,041 REFLECTS AMOUNTS PAID FOR ADDITIONAL FINANCIAL SUPPORT TO STUDENTS, INCLUDING PAYMENTS FOR HEALTH INSURANCE, LIVING EXPENSES, AND SUPPORT OF POSTDOCTORAL FELLOWS. THESE AMOUNTS INCLUDE $255,983 IN GRANTS TO INDIVIDUALS OUTSIDE THE UNITED STATES. GRANTS LISTED IN PART II ARE PRIMARILY GRANTS MADE FROM DONOR ADVISED FUNDS MANAGED BY STANFORD AND ARE BASED ON RECOMMENDATIONS BY DONORS OF THOSE FUNDS AND REVIEWED AND APPROVED BY SENIOR OFFICIALS IN THE UNIVERSITY OFFICE OF DEVELOPMENT. SUB-GRANTS STANFORD OCCASIONALLY RECEIVES GRANT SUPPORT THAT IS DISBURSED TO OTHER INDIVIDUALS OR ENTITIES PER THE TERMS OF THE AWARD. IN MOST CASES, PRIOR TO THE GRANT TO STANFORD, THE UNIVERSITY WILL PROVIDE THE GRANTING ENTITY WITH A LIST OF SUCH CONTEMPLATED RECIPIENTS. GENERALLY, AS WORK ON THE GRANT PROGRESSES, CHANGES TO THESE RECIPIENTS MUST BE APPROVED BY THE GRANTING AGENCY. DUE TO THESE REVIEW REQUIREMENTS OF THE GRANTING AGENCY, STANFORD DOES NOT REPORT SUCH PAYMENTS ON FORM 990, SCHEDULE I.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDES SCHOLARSHIPS AND FINANCIAL AID TO STUDENTS BASED ON NEED AND MERIT. THE FUNDS ARE CREDITED DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT. RECORDS ARE MAINTAINED IN ACCORDANCE WITH UNIVERSITY RETENTION AND DESTRUCTION POLICY. THE UNIVERSITY'S FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT ADHERES STRICTLY TO ALL FEDERAL AND STATE REGULATIONS AND IS SUBJECT TO THE COMPLIANCE AND INTERNAL CONTROLS OF OMB-A133 (IN WHICH THEY FOLLOW ALL APPLICABLE GUIDELINES).

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: PART I, LINE 2 - PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS
ExplntnTxt: STUDENTS ARE AWARDED SCHOLARSHIPS BASED ON AN EVALUATION OF NEED AND ELIGIBILITY FOR SPECIFIC AWARDS IN ACCORDANCE WITH ANY DONOR STIPULATIONS. THE FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT IS RESONSIBLE FOR MAKING SCHOLARSHIP AWARDS AND FOR MONITORING ONGOING ELIGIBILITY (E.G. MAINTENANCE OF SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS.)

The Organization only awards financial assistance or grant-in-aid to individuals who are designated to meet the educational expenses of students attending Fuller Theological Seminary. The Organization has established institutional policies for awarding and monitoring of financial assistance. Each award is done in accordance with the policies and compliance is monitored by senior management, to ensure that the amount and eligibility of individuals is in accordance with established policies.

The college's Office of Student Financial Services is responsible for awarding and monitoring all college, federal and state grant assistance. Approximately 67% of Wheaton students receive need based aid and all students who demonstrate need receive aid. Financial assistance at Wheaton is awarded on the basis of demonstrated need and academic performance. "Need" is determined by the financial information that a student and his/her family provides on the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) and CSS PROFILE forms which capture the data required to determine eligibility based on federal and/or state regulations and institutional fund eligibility guidelines. A need-based package may include a merit scholarship, grants, loans or work award. When funds are awarded, student eligibility is monitored through the college's operational system financial aid module to ensure there are no changes in status that might affect their ongoing eligibility. Total grant funds awarded are tracked to ensure compliance with budgeted amounts.
ALL SCHOLARSHIPS ARE IN THE FORM OF TUITION ASSISTANCE.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: RECORDS MAINTAINED FOR GRANTS OR ASSISTANCE
ExplntnTxt: SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2 The University has agreements with various government agencies regarding annual contributions. Also, Each year the University makes numerous small contributions to community organizations. THE UNIVERSITY'S Department of Community and Regional Affairs reviews requests from local non-profits, and looks to provide program support for organizations in the Princeton area who provide important services and resources to the community. All Contributions are evaluated to assure that they support the Princeton community at large. The University's Pace Center for Civic Engagement provides grants and support efforts by students, faculty, staff, and alumni to identify and address issues of public concern, to be actively engaged citizens, and to practice effective public leadership for the purpose of building stronger communities and societies throughout the world. THE UNDERGRADUATE FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT MAINTAINS THE RECORDS RELATED TO THE UNDERGRADUATE NEED-BASED GRANTS. THE PROCEDURE IS AS FOLLOWS: THE STUDENTS APPLY ANNUALLY FOR GRANTS BASED ON THEIR FAMILIES' FINANCIAL CIRCUMSTANCES. EACH APPLICATION IS THEN REVIEWED TO DETERMINE THE AMOUNT OF GRANT THAT IS NEEDED. THE GRANTS ARE PROVIDED FROM APPROPRIATE SOURCES AND APPLIED TO EACH STUDENT'S PRINCETON BILL FOR TUITION, FEES, ROOM, BOARD AND OTHER CHARGES. At the time of admission, graduate student fellowships are awarded on the basis of a combination of academic merit and financial need. All students must remain in good academic standing in order to receive funding. Students in certain programs receive research grants after their first year of study, While other students receive fellowships for the duration of their program. Graduate student fellowships are funded through a combination of university resources including endowment, general university funds, and/or departmental resources.

Schedule I, Part II In furtherance of its research activities, Princeton University makes sub-awards to other institutions that perform research in connection with research grants awarded to Princeton University. Princeton University does not categorize these sub-awards as "grants and other assistance" for Form 990 reporting, since the recipient organizations perform research services for the University and are considered independent contractors which serve the direct needs of the University. During the year ended June 30, 2018, Princeton University made sub-award payments to 192 recipient organizations totaling $29,975,106.

The College monitors the use of grant funds by verifying student enrollment records maintained by the Office of the Registrar and the Office of Student Accounts. Enrollment verification is performed prior to awarding of grant funds and throughout the academic year. The Office of Financial Aid monitors the College's compliance with grant agreement requirements throughout the academic year, and keeps current with compliance requirements by participating in professional development workshops and reviewing federal compliance updates from the Department of Education and NASFAA.

DOCUMENTATION IS MAINTAINED WHICH SUBSTANTIATES ELIGIBILITY AND THE AMOUNT OF ASSISTANCE GIVEN TO STUDENTS. NEED BASED ELIGIBILITY FOR SCHOLARSHIPS IS DETERMINED USING VARIOUS FACTORS TO ASSESS ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE OF THE STUDENT.

THE UNIVERSITY MONITORS ITS GRANTS TO ENSURE THAT SUCH GRANTS ARE USED FOR PROPER PURPOSES AND ARE NOT OTHERWISE DIVERTED FROM THEIR INTENDED USE BY HAVING THE ENROLLMENT SERVICES OFFICE PROVIDE THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE WITH A WEEKLY REPORT IDENTIFYING ANY FINANCIAL AID REFUNDS TO STUDENTS. THIS PROCESS ENSURES THAT ALL GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS ARE BEING APPLIED AND USED FOR THEIR INTENDED PURPOSE. ALL FINANCIAL AID IS ELECTRONICALLY POSTED DIRECTLY TO EACH STUDENTS ACCOUNT BY THE BURSAR.

OUR FINANCIAL AID OFFICE MONITORS THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS AND OTHER ASSISTANCE TO INDIVIDUALS IN THE UNITED STATES. THEY REVIEW EACH STUDENT TO VERIFY THEIR ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS FOR THE SPECIFIC GRANTS AND OTHER ASSISTANCE.

THE SEOG NUMBER OF RECIPIENTS IS BASED ON THE TOTAL NUMBER OF STUDENTS THAT RECEIVED SEOG FUNDS, BUT THE CASH GRANTS OF $46,333 IS ONLY THE INSTITUTIONAL SHARE OF FEDERAL SEOG.THE WORK-STUDY NUMBER OF RECIPIENTS IS BASED ON THE TOTAL NUMBER OF STUDENTS THAT RECEIVED FEDERAL WORK-STUDY FUNDS, BUT THE AMOUNT OF CASH GRANTS OF $270,472 IS ONLY THE INSTITUTIONAL SHARE OF FEDERAL WORK-STUDY.

EACH ACADEMIC YEAR THE OFFICE OF INSTITUTIONAL ADVANCEMENT PROVIDES THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID A DETAILED LIST OF THE COLLEGE'S ENDOWED SCHOLARSHIPS, ALONG WITH THE CURRENT MARKET VALUE OF EACH SCHOLARSHIP, AND STATED CRITERIA RESTRICTIONS, IF ANY, REQUIRED FOR RECIPIENTS OF THOSE SCHOLARSHIPS. THE OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID, FROM THAT LIST PROVIDED BY THE OFFICE OF INSTITUTIONAL AID, MATCHES STUDENTS WHO RECEIVE INSTITUTIONAL AID WITH THOSE ENDOWED SCHOLARSHIPS TO WHICH THEY ARE ELIGIBLE. THE LIST OF MATCHES IS THEN RETURNED TO THE OFFICE OF INSTITUTIONAL ADVANCEMENT.
ALL STUDENT SCHOLARSHIPS ARE POSTED TO THE STUDENT ACCOUNTS BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AND PAY FOR TUITION AND FEES. PER OTIS POLICY, BFA/MFA SCHOLARSHIPS DO NOT EXCEED TUITION AND FEES.
CITY UNIVERSITY OF SEATTLE PROVIDES SCHOLARSHIP GRANTS TO STUDENTS IN THE FORM OF TUITION REDUCTION. MONITORING IS DONE INTERNALLY TO ENSURE THE ACCOUNTS ARE CREDITED PROPERLY.

2 MEMBERS OF THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS FOR THE ORGANIZATION ARE ALSO BOARD OF DIRECTORS FOR SALISH KOOTENAI COLLEGE FOUNDATION AND THEY OVERSEE AND ENSURE THAT FUNDS ARE UTILIZED PROPERLY. SCHOLARSHIPS AND GRANTS ARE AWARDED TO STUDENTS OF THE COLLEGE BASED ON VARIOUS CRITERIA. THESE CRITERIA INCLUDE FINANCIAL NEED, GRADE POINT AVERAGE, AND OTHERS AS ESTABLISHED BY THE SCHOLARSHIP AND GRANT DOCUMENTS. SCHOLARSHIPS ARE APPLIED TO THE INDIVIDUAL STUDENTS' ACCOUNTS TO PAY TUITION, ROOM AND BOARD EXPENSES.

FOR THE GRANT IN THE AMOUNT OF $40,000 TO ARCHIVES OF THE EPISCOPAL CHURCH, EDS CONTINUES TO HAVE ACCESS TO MATERIALS TRANSFERRED TO THE ARCHIVES AND CAN THEREBY DETERMINE THE ARCHIVES' COMPLIANCE WITH THE TERMS OF THE GRANT. ON THE SCHOLARSHIPS TO STUDENTS, IN ORDER TO RECEIVE SCHOLARSHIP SUPPORT, STUDENTS MUST BE ENROLLED AT QUALIFYING INSTITUTIONS, AND THOSE INSTITUTIONS CONFIRM THE RECIPIENTS' ENROLLMENT TO EDS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part II, Line 1(h) Explanation of purpose of grant or assistance
ExplntnTxt: Payments related to work performed on research subcontract related to federal, state or private grant originally made to the University and other assistance in accordance with the University's exempt mission.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: ALL GRANTS MADE FOR RESEARCH ACTIVITIES ARE INITIATED BY A FORMAL SUB-CONTRACT EXECUTED BY BOTH PARTIES. THE TERMS AND CONDITIONS OF EACH GRANT CONTAIN ALL THE GUIDELINES FOR INVOICING, BILLING, RECORD RETENTION, AUDITS, ETC. RESEARCH AND SPONSORED PROGRAMS ACCOUNTING ("RSPA") AND THE NOTRE DAME RESEARCH OFFICE WORK IN TANDEM TO ENSURE THE GUIDELINES ARE ADHERED TO. ALMOST ALL SUBCONTRACTS FOR RESEARCH ACTIVITIES ARE PAID ON A COST REIMBURSEMENT BASIS. ALL INVOICES PAID FOR COSTS ARE APPROVED BY THE PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR BASED ON COMPLETION OF WORK, DELIVERABLES MET, ETC. IN ADDITION, RSPA MONITORS THE PAYMENTS AGAINST THE TOTAL BUDGET TO ENSURE PAYMENT IS NOT MADE ABOVE THE STIPULATED CEILING. THE UNIVERSITY HAS A POLICY CONTAINING GUIDELINES SURROUNDING SUB-CONTRACTS, SOME OF WHICH WERE ADDRESSED ABOVE. THIS POLICY CAN BE FOUND AT: HTTP://CONTROLLER.ND.EDU/ASSETS/91679/SUBRECIPIENT_MONITORING.PDF. CHARITABLE ORGANIZATIONS THAT RECEIVE CONTRIBUTIONS FROM THE UNIVERSITY ARE CAREFULLY SELECTED AND REQUIRE DOCUMENTATION TO SUPPORT THE UNIVERSITY'S INTEREST IN THE ORGANIZATION TO ENSURE CONSISTENCY WITH THE CORE VALUES OF THE UNIVERSITY. CHARITABLE CONTRIBUTIONS ALSO REQUIRE THE APPROVAL OF THE EXECUTIVE VICE PRESIDENT, EXCEPT FOR THOSE CHARITABLE CONTRIBUTIONS MADE THROUGH THE UNIVERSITY'S DONOR ADVISED FUND PROGRAM, WHICH UNDERGO A THOROUGH VETTING PROCESS BY THE UNIVERSITY'S TAX DEPARTMENT TO ENSURE THE RECIPIENT ORGANIZATION MEETS THE IRS'S DEFINITION OF A 501(C)(3) NOT FOR PROFIT CHARITABLE ORGANIZATION. THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDES FUNDING TO STUDENTS AND OTHER RELATED INDIVIDUALS FOR RESEARCH AND OTHER ACTIVITIES TO SUPPORT THE FURTHERANCE OF THEIR EDUCATION. FUNDS PROVIDED ARE MONITORED THROUGH APPLICATIONS, BUDGETS AND A REQUIREMENT TO DOCUMENT THE USE OF FUNDS EITHER PRIOR TO THE DISTRIBUTION OF FUNDS OR UPON COMPLETION OF THE ACTIVITY.

THE FOUNDATION UTILIZES AN ONLINE SCHOLARSHIP APPLICATION PROCESS. THE PROGRAM USES ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS TO FILTER APPLICANTS BASED ON DONOR CRITERIA. THE FOUNDATION AWARDS 4% (UNLESS OTHERWISE DIRECTED BY DONOR(S)) OF FUND BALANCE FOR SCHOLARSHIPS. ONCE THE APPLICATION PROCESS HAS ENDED, THE COMMITTEES WILL SCORE THE COMPLETED APPLICATIONS AND MAKE THE DETERMINATION FOR THE AWARD. FOUNDATION STAFF WILL THEN WORK WITH THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE OF BBCC TO MAKE THE FINAL AWARD.
ALL SCHOLARSHIPS ARE MONITORED FOR APPROPRIATE USE BY MONITORING REGISTRATION AND SATISFACTORY COMPLETION OF COURSES AND PROGRAMS TOWARDS EDUCATIONAL REQUIREMENTS.

FINANCIAL AID AWARDS TO STUDENTS AT POINT PARK UNIVERSITY ARE DETERMINED ON THE BASIS OF ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, COMMUNITY SERVICE, ARTISTIC OR ATHLETIC TALENT AND FINANCIAL NEED ELIGIBILITY. GRANTS AND LOANS ARE DISTRIBUTED USING POWERFAIDS APPLICATION AND POSTED TO STUDENT'S ACCOUNTS IN JENZABAR (HIGHER EDUCATION INFORMATION SYSTEM). ANNUALLY THE FINANCIAL AID AREA IS AUDITED BY AN INDEPENDENT ACCOUNTING FIRM.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: The organization uses congressional methodology from the US Department of Education's need analysis. It assigns student eligibility based on effective family contribution from the Pell Processing Center. All records on packaging as well as awarding are processed through the organization's PowerFAIDS system.
All grants are issued through the UDM Financial Aid office. The FA counselors communicate with students and monitor students' status and educational programs.

Olin College provides all accepted students with merit scholarships which cover half of their tuition and are credited directly to their student accounts. The scholarships are only used to offset tuition charges.

MONITORING USE OF GRANT FUNDS - ALL GRANT-RELATED REVENUES AND EXPENSES AWARDED TO THE COLLEGE ARE ACCOUNTED FOR IN SEPARATE AND DISTINCT RESTRICTED FUNDS WITHIN THE COLLEGE'S FINANCIAL SYSTEM. WITHIN THE ACCOUNTING OFFICE, A GRANT FILE IS ESTABLISHED FOR EACH RESTRICTED GRANT FUND WHICH CONTAINS THE GRANTOR-APPROVED BUDGET AND AWARD LETTER AMONG OTHER PERTINENT INFORMATION RELATED TO THE GRANTS, SUCH AS POLICIES OF THE GRANTOR. A FULL-TIME STAFF ACCOUNTANT IS ASSIGNED TO MONITOR THE EXPENDITURE OF THE GRANT FUNDS IN TERMS OF THE GRANT BUDGET, FUNDS AVAILABILITY AND ALLOWABILITY. FINANCIAL REPORTS ARE PREPARED BY THE STAFF ACCOUNTANT AND REVIEWED BY THE CONTROLLER PRIOR TO SUBMISSION TO THE GRANTING AGENCY. LAKE ERIE COLLEGE'S OFFICE OF FINANCIAL AID MAINTAINS RECORDS TO COMPLY WITH GRANTOR'S CRITERIA FOR AWARDING FUNDS TO INDIVIDUAL STUDENTS. STUDENT INFORMATION IS REVIEWED AND MAINTAINED IN A POWERFAIDS DATABASE AND STUDENT FILES TO DETERMINE ELIGIBILITY FOR GRANTS.

YOUNG HARRIS COLLEGE DEVELOPS FINANCIAL AID AWARDS BASED UPON A COMBINATION OF FACTORS, INCLUDING THE STUDENT'S DEMONSTRATED FINANCIAL NEED AS DETERMINED BY THE FAFSA OR OTHER FAMILY FINANCIAL INDICATOR AS ACCEPTED BY THE COLLEGE, HIGH SCHOOL GPA, AND SAT OR ACT SCORES. AID IS TO BE AWARDED IN THE MANNER WHICH BEST SERVES THE GREATEST NUMBER OF STUDENTS AND WHICH IS IN KEEPING WITH THE INTENT OF THE VARIOUS CAMPUS PROGRAMS. ALL INSTITUTIONAL FINANCIAL AID AWARDS ARE MADE IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE STUDENT'S ABILITY TO MAINTAIN SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS. THE FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT MONITORS THE STUDENTS' SATISFACTORY ACADEMIC PROGRESS ANNUALLY FOR INSTITUTIONAL AID TO DETERMINE CONTINUED ELIGIBILITY. STANDARDS ARE SET ON QUALITATIVE AND QUANTITATIVE PROGRESS.

ALL STUDENTS APPLYING FOR FEDERAL FUNDS ARE REQUIRED TO SUBMIT THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID ("FAFSA"). THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE REVIEWS THE RESULTS OF THE FAFSA, WHICH DICTATES WHAT AND HOW MUCH FEDERAL FUNDING THE INDIVIDUAL STUDENT IS ELIGIBLE FOR. IF THE STUDENT IS DETERMINED TO BE IN COMPLIANCE WITH ALL FEDERAL REGULATIONS, AS DETERMINED BY THE DEPT. OF ED., THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AWARDS THE STUDENT THE APPROPRIATE FUNDING. STUDENT FILES REGARDING ELIGIBILITY ARE MAINTAINED BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE.

GRANTS TO INDIVIDUALS COVER TUITION FOR STUDENTS ATTENDING THE COLLEGE. TRANSPORTATION AND MEDICAL EXPENSES ARE GENERALLY PAID DIRECTLY ON BEHALF OF GRANTEES. STUDENTS WHO MEET ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS ARE PROVIDED GRANTS FOR DAILY ESSENTIALS. GRANTS TO DOMESTIC ORGANIZATIONS ARE MADE ON A REIMBURSEMENT BASIS AFTER SUBMISSION OF RECEIPTS..

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING USE OF GRANT FUNDS
ExplntnTxt: For contributions under $1,000,000, Wheaton College will generally retain 25%; for contributions of over $1,000,000, Wheaton College will generally retain 10%. The remaining portion of each donor's contribution is available for distribution to other public charities at the donor's recommendation, subject to the approval of the Wheaton College Charity Selection Committee. The Committee must review and approve all recommendations. Such review includes: verifying exempt status, identifying the mission of the organization and the purpose of the grant, and review of the organization's Form 990, if applicable.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: Grants and scholarships are awarded to students who apply for financial assistance at Wheaton College. Grant recipients are based on financial need. All funds are used for tuition and books and living expenses at Wheaton College. This process is monitored by the Financial Aid Office at the College.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Form Sch I Part I Line 2
ExplntnTxt: GRANT SUBSTANTIATION THE ORGANIZATION FOLLOWS FEDERAL, STATE AND INSTITUTIONAL GUIDELINES AND METHODOLOGIES FOR DETERMINING ELIGIBILITY AND AWARDING OF NEED-BASED FINANCIAL AID. FOR MERIT-BASED GRANTS, THE ORGANIZATION AWARDS THE GRANTS IN COMPLIANCE WITH THE STIPULATIONS OF THE UNDERLYING GOVERNING INSTRUMENT (I.E. DONOR ENDOWMENT AGREEMENTS, AND OTHER DONOR DOCUMENTATION). THE ORGANIZATION MAINTAINS DETAILED RECORDS OF COMPLIANCE FOR ALL GRANTS DISPERSED. ASSISTANCE TO MOREHOUSE COLLEGE STUDENTS IN THE FORM OF SCHOLARSHIPS ARE AWARDED FOR THE PURPOSE OF AIDING WITH THE COST OF ATTENDING THE UNIVERSITY, I.E. FOR TUITION, HOUSING, AND MEALS. SCHOLARSHIPS ARE BASED ON ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, NEED, AND OTHER DONOR REQUIREMENTS SUCH AS LOCATION OF RESIDENCE. MOREHOUSE COLLEGE HAS CRITERIA FOR THE ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS NEEDED TO AWARD A SCHOLARSHIP.
GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS ARE MONITORED FOR APPROPRIATE USE BY VALIDATING REGISTRATION AND SATISFACTORY PROGRESS TOWARDS COMPLETION OF EDUCATIONAL REQUIREMENTS.

THE COLLEGE HISTORICALLY AWARDED FULL-TUITION SCHOLARSHIPS TO ALL ENROLLED STUDENTS. FOLLOWING A PROVISIONAL REDUCTION IN 2014 OF SCHOLARSHIPS TO A MINIMUM 50% OF TUITION FOR FISCAL REASONS (CURRENTLY THE AVERAGE STUDENT RECEIVES 70%), THE COLLEGE IS NOW EXECUTING A BOARD-APPROVED PLAN WITH A GOAL OF RETURNING WITHIN TEN YEARS TO ITS PRACTICE OF AWARDING FULL-TUITION SCHOLARSHIPS TO ALL ENROLLED STUDENTS IF THE COLLEGE MEETS ITS FINANCIAL TARGETS. THE COLLEGE DESIGNATED A TUITION RATE OF $43,250 FOR FULL-TIME UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS FOR THE 2017-2018 ACADEMIC YEAR. STUDENTS WHO CAN DEMONSTRATE NEED, AS CALCULATED BY THE FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID, MAY BE ELIGIBLE FOR ADDITIONAL FINANCIAL AID. COOPER UNION AWARDS FEDERAL PELL GRANTS, AND FEDERAL SEOG GRANTS, AS WELL AS COOPER UNION GRANTS, TO STUDENTS WHO MEET THE ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS.

Monitoring the use of grants: The office of Financial Aid processes all students' financial aid awards based on guidelines set forth by federal, state and local governments. These awards are included in the student financial package and are applied to the students' accounts once all eligibility requirements are met. The Office of Financial Aid reconciles all federal funds to the US Department of Education Common Origination and Disbursement system on a monthly basis. In addition, the Controller's Office reconciles the award disbursement activities posted to the Institute's General Ledger account to the Students' Accounts receivable ledgers and Financial Aid awards reports. The Controller's Office also processes the reimbursement requests and reconciliation of funds received, and monitors the spending level to ensure that actual disbursements does not exceed the authorized government grant.
SCHOLARSHIPS AND FINANCIAL AID ARE BASED ON APPLICATION PROCESS, EXPECTED FAMILY CONTRIBUTIONS AND COST OF TUITION.

The College awards scholarships and financial aid awards. These funds are disbursed by the College's Financial Aid Department in strict adherence to all Federal and state regulations. The College also grants money to Earlham Foundation, a related organization, to hold and invest the assets on the College's behalf.
FINANCIAL AID VERIFIES ELIGIBILITY AND AWARDS APPROPRIATELY. FUNDS ARE TRANSFERRED TO STUDENT ACCOUNTS TO COVER FEES. NO OVER-AWARDING IS PERMITTED.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS IN THE U.S.
ExplntnTxt: SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2 ALL FUNDS DONATED BY INDIVIDUALS, CORPORATIONS OR FOUNDATIONS ARE RECORDED AS TEMPORARILY RESTRICTED UNTIL FUNDS ARE IDENTIFIED AS APPLICABLE TO FINANCIAL AID FOR A STUDENT. FUNDS ARE SUBSEQUENTLY CREDITED TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNTS. ALL AWARDS ARE UNDER THE DIRECTION OF THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE WITH DONORS' DIRECTIONS.

SCHEDULE I, PART III SCHOLARSHIPS FOR WOMEN MAKING LIFE CHANGES THROUGH EDUCATION, PER DONOR RESTRICTIONS, AMOUNTED TO $ 101,063 SCHOLARSHIP FOR TEACHERS AND SOCIAL SERVICES STUDENTS IN THE BOSTON AREA SEEKING TO ADVANCE THEIR CAREERS THROUGH EDUCATION, PER DONOR RESTRICTIONS, AMOUNTED TO $ 38,016 SCHOLARSHIPS FOR STUDENT WORKING TOWARDS CIVIL RIGHTS AND SOCIAL JUSTICE IN THEIR PERSONAL LIVES OR EDUCATION, PER DONOR RESTRICTIONS, AMOUNTED TO $ 29,799 SCHOLARSHIPS FOR STUDENTS MAKING LIFE CHANGES THROUGH EDUCATION, PER DONOR RESTRICTIONS, AMOUNTED TO $ 24,900 SCHOLARSHIPS FOR MALE PROTESTANT STUDENTS FROM BOSTON AREA SCHOOLS, PER DONOR RESTRICTIONS, AMOUNTED TO $5,820 STUDENTS WITH HERITAGE FROM LAOS, BURMA, CAMBODIA, AND VIETNAM AMOUNTED TO $ 14,145 THE REMAINING $544,812 IS COMPRISED OF FINANCIAL AID ($339,773), MASSACHUSETTS GRANTS ($118,599), AND WAIVERS & DISCOUNTS ($86,440).

THE GRANTEE WAS REQUIRED TO SIGN AND RETURN A GRANT AWARD LETTER THAT STIPULATES THE TERMS AND CONDITIONS OF THE GRANT INCLUDING HOW THE DOLLARS ARE TO BE SPENT, OVER WHAT PERIOD OF TIME AND REPORTING REQUIREMENTS. THE ORGANIZATION REQUESTS WRITTEN REPORTS FROM GRANTEES WITHIN 6-9 MONTHS OF RECEIVING THE GRANT. IN SELECTED CASES, SITE VISITS ARE CONDUCTED TO MONITOR THE PROGRESS OF FUNDED PROGRAMS.

PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING GRANTS THE TRUSTEES OF THE UNIVERSITY OF PENNSYLVANIA'S ("PENN") OFFICE OF RESEARCH SERVICES IS RESPONSIBLE FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS PURSUANT TO ESTABLISHED POLICES AND PROTOCOL. THESE POLICIES COVER GRANTS MADE BOTH WITHIN AND OUTSIDE THE U.S. -------------------- TO PROMOTE INCLUSION AND INCREASED ACCESS, PENN PROVIDES GRANT-BASED UNDERGRADUATE FINANCIAL AID PACKAGES AND ADHERES TO A NEED-BLIND ADMISSION POLICY, IN WHICH ADMISSION DECISIONS ARE NOT AFFECTED BY A STUDENTS ABILITY TO PAY OR APPLICATION FOR FINANCIAL AID. THIS POLICY PROVIDES FINANCIAL AID TO ELIGIBLE STUDENTS IN THE FORM OF DIRECT GRANTS AND EMPLOYMENT DURING THE ACADEMIC YEAR. STUDENTS MAY STILL BORROW AT THEIR DISCRETION TO SUPPLEMENT THEIR AID PACKAGES. AN UNDERGRADUATE STUDENT MAY ALSO BE ELIGIBLE FOR FACULTY/STAFF TUITION REMISSION AS A RESULT OF A PARENT BEING ELIGIBLE TO RECEIVE THIS BENEFIT AS A CONDITION OF THEIR EMPLOYMENT. GRADUATE/PROFESSIONAL FINANCIAL AID CAN BE AWARDED BASED ON FINANCIAL NEED, SERVICE (TEACHING ASSISTANTSHIPS AND FELLOWSHIPS, RESEARCH ASSISTANTSHIPS AND FELLOWSHIPS) OR OTHER CRITERIA SUCH AS MERIT/ACADEMICS. PHD STUDENTS GENERALLY RECEIVE MULTI-YEAR AWARDS COVERING THEIR FULL EDUCATIONAL COSTS. A GRADUATE/PROFESSIONAL STUDENT MAY ALSO BE ELIGIBLE FOR FACULTY/STAFF BENEFIT AS DESCRIBED ABOVE. -----------------------------------------

DETAIL OF SUB-CONTRACTS IN FURTHERANCE OF ITS RESEARCH ACTIVITIES, THE TRUSTEES OF THE UNIVERSITY OF PENNSYLVANIA MAKES SUB-AWARDS TO OTHER INSTITUTIONS THAT PERFORM RESEARCH IN CONNECTION WITH RESEARCH GRANTS AWARDED TO THE UNIVERSITY. THE UNIVERSITY DOES NOT CATEGORIZE THESE SUB-AWARDS AS "GRANTS AND ASSISTANCE" FOR FORM 990 REPORTING, SINCE THE RECIPIENT ORGANIZATIONS PERFORM RESEARCH SERVICES FOR THE UNIVERSITY AND ARE CONSIDERED INDEPENDENT CONTRACTORS WHICH SERVE THE DIRECT NEEDS OF THE UNIVERSITY. DURING THE YEAR ENDED JUNE 30, 2018, THE UNIVERSITY OF PENNSYLVANIA MADE SUB-AWARD PAYMENTS TO 327 RECIPIENTS TOTALING $115,558,159.

SCHEDULE I, Part I, Line 2 SINCE ITS INCEPTION, MANAGEMENT REVIEWS REQUESTS FOR GRANTS. TOURO UNIVERSITY NEVADA MONITORS ALL REQUESTS FOR USE OF GRANT FUNDS AGAINST THE SUBMITTED BUDGETS FOR THE RESPECTIVE GRANTS. PRIOR TO SUBMISSION OF REQUESTS FOR REIMBURSEMENT, ADDITIONAL REVIEW OF EXPENDED FUNDS IS PERFORMED TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE WITH GRANT AND UNIVERSITY GUIDELINES. STUDENTS ARE AWARDED TUITION DISCOUNTS BASED ON VARIOUS CRITERIA. THE DISCOUNTS ARE CREDITED TO THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNTS.
FINANCIAL AID AND SCHOLARSHIPS FOR OLIVET COLLEGE STUDENTS ENROLLED AND ATTENDING CLASSES. ALL RECORDS ARE RETAINED BY THE COLLEGE.

SCHOLARSHIPS ARE GIVEN TO INDIVIDUALS BASED ON NEED AND MERIT TO AID WITH TUITION AND FEES. SCHOLARSHIPS ARE A REDUCTION OF TUITION AND FEES AND PROVIDED DIRECTLY BY THE UNIVERSITY. RECORDS ARE MAINTAINED FOR ELIGIBILITY AND THE SELECTION CRITERIA.

FUNDS ARE DISTRIBUTED TO STUDENTS BASED ON NEED AND MERIT. STUDENT AID IS HANDLED BY THE FINANCIAL AID OFFICE AND CREDITED DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENT ACCOUNT. EACH STUDENT APPLIES FOR FINANCIAL AID BY FILLING OUT A FREE APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL STUDENT AID (FAFSA). THE AWARD IS BASED ON THE INFORMATION IN THIS APPLICATION. STUDENTS CAN ALSO APPLY FOR GRANTS AND SCHOLARSHIPS BASED ON ELIGIBILITY. THERE IS AN AWARD ELIGIBILITY CALCULATOR ON THE HEIDELBERG WEBSITE TO SEE IF YOU QUALIFY.

ALL GRANTS ARE FINANCIAL AID AND APPLIED DIRECTLY TO STUDENT ACCOUNTS. IT IS A CONTINUAL PROCESS IN WHICH WE AWARD STUDENT AID WITHIN FEDERAL GUIDELINES AT THE INITIAL AWARDING TIME PERIOD. IF ANY CHANGES TO A STUDENT'S STATUS OCCUR, WE REVIEW THE STUDENT'S AID PACKAGE COMPONENTS TO ENSURE THAT ANY/ALL ADJUSTMENTS MADE MAINTAIN COMPLIANCE WITH TITLE IV FUND RULES. OUR ASSISTANT DIRECTOR OF COMPLIANCE RUNS REPORTS, DAILY, WEEKLY, AND MONTHLY TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part III PRIZES AND AWARDS
ExplntnTxt: PRIZES AND AWARDS REFLECT PRIZES AND AWARDS EXTENDED TO NON-EMPLOYEES IN RECOGNITION OF AN ACCOMPLISHMENT, ACTIVITY, OR EVENT. PRIZES AND AWARDS GIVEN TO EMPLOYEES ARE INCLUDED AS COMPENSATION AND REPORTED ON AN EMPLOYEE'S FORM W-2.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: Explanation: Grants given to support of charitable community organizations. Such grants are extended only for charitable purposes to organizations that are exempt under Code Section 501(c)(3). After qualifications for the grant are met and the grant is disbursed to the charitable organization there is no subsequent monitoring by the University. Grants or other assistance are awarded to organizations or entities in the U.S. pursuant to the University policies and procedures for all grant subawards. Such subawards are monitored through the University's office for Sponsored Research (OSR) and the University's Office of Accounting Services for Research and Sponsored Programs (ASRSP). All subaward documentation including purchase orders, related charges and invoices are reviewed and monitored by ASRSP and confirmed with the principal investigator. The principal investigator must certify that the subaward costs are in accordance with the Office of Management and Budget's (OMB) Uniform Guidance (Uniform Administrative Requirements, Cost Principles, and Audit Requirements); also, ASRSP requests and collects audit reports from subaward recipients to monitor compliance, as required by the Uniform Guidance. If the information is not furnished to ASRSP, payment may be withheld.
THE FUNDS ARE USED AS SCHOLARSHIPS AT GRATZ COLLEGE AND ARE DIRECTLY CREDITED TO THE RECIPIENT'S TUITION
THE FINANCIAL AID DIRECTOR AT EACH CAMPUS IS GIVEN AN AMOUNT THAT MAY BE AWARDED AT THEIR CAMPUS FOR THE FISCAL YEAR, WITH A CHART OF HOW MANY STUDENTS AND THE AMOUNT FOR EACH TERM.

PSC PROVIDES SCHOLARSHIPS AND FINANCIAL AID TO INDIVIDUALS TO ATTEND THE COLLEGE. THE SCHOLARSHIPS AND AID FOR SUCH STUDENTS ARE AWARDED BASED ON NEED AND MERIT AND COVER THE COSTS OF TUITION, ROOM, AND BOARD. THE SCHOLARSHIP AND/OR FINANCIAL AID IS AWARDED BASED ON INSTITUTIONAL POLICY AND STANDARDS SET FORTH BY THE DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION AND THE STATE OF ARKANSAS. THE COLLEGE'S FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT MONITORS THE COMPLIANCE WITH SUCH REGULATIONS. THE SCHOLARSHIP AND/OR FINANCIAL AID IS APPLIED BY THE FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT DIRECTLY AGAINST THE STUDENT'S ACCOUNT WITH THE COLLEGE AS A REDUCTION IN FEES. AS A RESULT, THE GRANT CAN ONLY BE USED FOR ITS INTENDED PURPOSE (I.E. COST OF ATTENDANCE) AND CANNOT BE DIVERTED FROM THIS USE.

The University awards grants, scholarships & student loans based on various, predefined criteria. Students must qualify for the assistance. Student enrollment and continuing eligibility are verified on an ongoing basis. Any amounts in excess of $600.00 are reported on Form 1098-T. No cash changes hands and funds are directly applied to student accounts.

Monitoring the Use of Grants On rare occasion, the University will match funds raised by students for worthy charitable projects. All such funds are reviewed carefully by the VP for Student Life and approved by the President upon the recommendation of the Student Government Association. Other grants may be permitted in furtherance of the University's mission and are approved by the President.

Grants and Other Assistance to Individuals The University has financial aid available in many forms, including scholarships and grants. The eligibility for financial aid is based upon student's achievement and promise, academic credentials and financial need.
For the room and board grant amounts, the number of recipients is not disclosed as these students are already included in Lines 2,3 and 4.
FINANCIAL AID AWARDS ARE PROVIDED AS SCHOLARSHIPS FOR STUDENTS. THE FUNDS ARE APPLIED DIRECTLY TO THE STUDENTS' TUITION AND FEES.

MONITOR THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS: THE UNIVERSITY'S GRANTS IN THE U.S. CONSIST OF FINANCIAL AID AWARDS WHICH ARE APPLIED AGAINST STUDENTS' RECEIVABLE BALANCES DUE TO THE UNIVERSITY. THE UNIVERSITY MONITORS THESE GRANTS BY CONTROLLING THE APPLICATION OF GRANTS TO STUDENTS' BALANCES.

Financial Aid and Satisfactory Academic Progress Standards: To remain at Knox, all degree-seeking students are expected to make satisfactory academic progress. Satisfactory progress is defined both in terms of the accumulation of credits toward the degree, and the maintenance of a grade point average consistent with graduation requirements. The Financial Aid Office follows the decisions of the Academic Standing Committee in determining whether a student is meeting the College's satisfactory academic progress standards.
Grant funds are credited to student accounts in the form of need-based financial aid that reduce the comprehensive fee.
The funds awarded to the students are disbursed directly to the College as the student enrolls in courses.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
ExplntnTxt: Financial Aid Eligibility Requirements * Complete the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) annually and as early as January 1 (Temple's priority deadline is March 1) * Sign statements on the FAFSA stating that: * you are not in default on a federal student loan and do not owe money on a federal student grant and * you will use federal student aid only for educational purposes * Comply with Temple University's Satisfactory Academic Progress Standards * Remain in good standing on educational loans and grants per the National Student Loan Database System (NSLDS) * Remain enrolled at least part-time per semester for Federal loans (6 credits as an undergraduate student and 4.5 credits as a graduate student) * Be enrolled in an eligible degree program at Temple University * Be a citizen or eligible non-citizen with a valid Social Security Number * Have a high school diploma or recognized equivalent * Be registered for the Selective Service if you are male and 18-25 years of age * Comply with any and all federal verification requests made by Student Financial Services Research Administration Processing an Award - Negotiation of SubAward(s) If the University receives an award and a portion of the activity is to be sub-contracted to another entity, Sponsored Programs assists the PI in development of a sub-contract which outlines the sub-contractor's role in meeting the requirements of the award. Sponsored Programs forwards the sub-contract to the sub-contractor for review and signature. Upon return of the executed document, the PI should complete a Financial Impact Statement. Sponsored Programs forwards the sub-contract and Financial Impact Statement to University Counsel, where review and appropriate signature(s) and seal (if necessary) are obtained. When the University is the recipient of a sub-contract similar procedures are followed.

The King's College continuously monitors the academic progress of students receiving scholarship and financial aid funds. All scholarships and financial aid and housing grants are applied directly to the student accounts and therefore, no cash changes hands.
Policy guides, accounting software, and annual audit.

THE COLLEGE PROVIDES SCHOLARSHIPS TO ENROLLED STUDENTS. AMOUNTS AWARDED ARE DETERMINED BY THE FINANCIAL AID DEPARTMENT IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE COLLEGE'S AND FEDERAL AGENCY POLICIES. AMOUNTS GIVEN ARE CREDITED TO THE STUDENTS ACCOUNT.

PROCEDURES FOR MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS THE UNIVERSITY HAS DEVELOPED A QUANTIFIED ANALYSIS OF OUR AWARDING PRACTICES AND POLICIES. THESE PRACTICES AND POLICIES ARE REVIEWED ANNUALLY TO DETERMINE WHETHER CHANGES ARE NEEDED TO OUR PHILOSOPHY AND FINANCIAL AID PACKAGING PHILOSOPHY.

The College follows federal, state, donor, and institutional guidelines for determining eligibility for scholarships, prizes, and other grants and awards. The College maintains records showing the selection criteria, recipient eligibility, how funds may be used, and any related party. Before paying grants to other entities, the College obtains documentation showing the recipient is eligible to receive deductible charitable contributions. Grants awarded by the Office of Financial Aid are credited directly to student accounts. Other grants are monitored in various ways, including reimbursing actual substantiated expenses, requiring written reports, and/or visiting sites of activities funded by the College grants.

SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2 DAVIDSON COLLEGE FOLLOWS FEDERAL, STATE AND INSTITUTIONAL GUIDELINES AND METHODOLOGIES FOR DETERMINING ELIGIBILITY AND AWARDING OF NEED-BASED FINANCIAL AID. MONITORED BY SCHOLARSHIP COMMITTEE
All expenditures of Scholarship and Financial Aid grant funds are approved and monitored by the Financial Aid department for each student receiving funds.

GRADUATE/PROFESSIONAL FINANCIAL AID CAN BE AWARDED BASED ON FINANCIAL NEED, SERVICE (TEACHING ASSISTANTSHIPS AND FELLOWSHIPS, RESEARCH ASSISTANTSHIPS AND FELLOWSHIPS) OR OTHER CRITERIA SUCH AS MERIT/ACADEMICS.
